## Do you have what you need?

Learners will:

-   Know when a situation should be a rapid vs. a code

-   Know when unique personnel or resources are needed

-   Be able to organize responding personnel

## First Scenario

### Paged to bedside at U of U Hospital

-   Middle-aged man, new tachycardia & BP 65/42.

-   Oxygenating 90% on 2L by nasal cannula

-   Disoriented, somnolent, and diaphoretic

[What do you do?]{.underline}

## Analyze the Emergency

### Stable or Unstable?

-   ABCs

-   What help do you have?

-   What help do you **need?**

    -   Charge RN to expedite transfer?

    -   Phlebotomy for labs?

    -   XRay, Respiratory?\*

[What do you need in this situation?]{.underline}

## Second Scenario

### Paged to RRT at the VA

-   Elderly male who is hypoxemic immediately after a blood transfusion

-   RR 24, SpO2 82% on room air

Sick or not sick? Stable or Unstable? [What else do you need?]{.underline}

## Situations to Escalate

### Code Blue

+----------------------+--------------------------------------------------------+
| STEMI, or suspicion  | Shock Team                                             |
+----------------------+--------------------------------------------------------+
| Activate Cath Lab    | HF, few comorbidities. VT Storm. High Suspicion for PE |
+----------------------+--------------------------------------------------------+
| All Sites Capable    | Shock Team (U of U). PERT Team (IMC) / TICU            |
+----------------------+--------------------------------------------------------+

## Second Scenario, cont.

### You call a code blue. Shortly, the patient loses their pulse.

-   Anesthesia at head of bed preparing to intubate

-   Single compressor starting to tire

-   Pharmacist trying to hand epi to RN on far end of the room

[How can we improve things?]{.underline}

## Room Management

::: columns
::: {.column width="55%"}
-   Bed out from wall (for airway), rotate bed (for compressor space)
-   Drop the bed (for CPR)
-   "Everyone clear out unless I've given you a role"
:::

::: {.column width="45%"}
![Bed Management](images/clipboard-1132860432.png)
:::
:::

## Summary

-   Is this rapid really a code? Can't breathe, extremis

-   Situations where you need other people? Airway, Cath/Shock Team, Neuro

-   Room control: move the bed out, lower the bed, send people away
